Many of the sensors noted above are self calibrating on a short-term basis (some are daily) however, annually these sensors are confirmed to be accurate (calibrated). Similarly, flow meters and other sensors are calibrated annually and tested to confirm proper operation.

Five Year Accident History
The subject facilities have been in operation about 5 years and there have been no accidents

Emergency Response Program
As noted, Schirm has been subject to the emergency response requirements of the OSHA standard for many years. The procedures have been established in cooperation with local emergency responders.

The procedures require that all workers are trained in the emergency response procedures. Training includes identification of various possible emergency situations and how to respond. Some major aspects include:
¿	Annual fire extinguisher training
¿	How to shut down equipment in an emergency
¿	Periodic fire drills
¿	Emergency numbers (copies are posted on or near every phone)
¿	To what extent they should attempt to correct a situation with cautions about not attempting to handle major upset events
¿	They are told the locations of safety equipment
¿	How to use the notification equipment
¿	The proper personal protective equipment is identified

A response team has been identified to provide coordination in case of emergencies.

A notification sequence has been prepared which identifies the order of notification of the response

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The Schirm USA commitment is that our service will comply with all regulatory requirements and will meet or exceed the expectation of our customers in:

¿	QUALITY
¿	SAFETY
¿	ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION
¿	COMMUNITY CONSIDERATION

Schirm USA has long been committed to safe operations. To prevent accidental releases Schirm has worked closely with local responders for many years and particularly involved them during design and construction of the facilities handling the RMP regulated substance. The facility operating procedures are intended minimize the possibility of any kind of upset or malfunction (i.e., help ensure safe operation).  In the event there were some sort of malfunction, the emergency response procedures are designed to minimize hazards to human health and to the environment: in the event of spills, fires, explosion or any sudden release of hazardous substance to air, soil, or surface water.

Examples of Schirm's commitment to safety particularly to the process subject to RMP include the fact that during design and construction local emergency responders were asked to provide input.  Also, Schirm identified potential operators in early phases of plant design. These operators were present during the design and construction and even provided some input. Having the intimate knowledge of the plant helps these operators to be better operators and more aware of potential safety problems. In addition, numerous equipment redundancies and safeguards including automation of many tasks to help minimize the possibility of human error have been included in the plant which are aimed totally at increasing the safety of the plant. Such extra measures required a large commitment of resources and help demonstrate a strong commitment to safety.

Although very familiar with the facility, operating personnel are given emergency response training specific to the subject facilities over

and above the regular emergency response training. 

The Facilities and Regulated Substances
Incorporated originally as Agriculture Warehouse, Inc. in 1976, Schirm USA, Inc., was formed to serve the Agricultural Chemical Industry with Warehousing, Formulation and Packaging, as a third party for several industry clients. Whether solid or liquid, formulation involves various ingredients being mixed together either in a blender-type device or in a stirring-type device. This is a mixing operation. 

Another facet of the business (in addition to formulating) involves re-packaging of many of the same products. The re-packaging normally involves receiving finished product from our clients in bulk format and loading it into specialized consumer-d packaging according to customer specification. 

None of the above activities involve complex chemical reactions.

The two facilities subject to the Risk Management Plan (RMP) requirements were newly constructed in 2008 and added a new type of process to the activities performed at the Schirm site, namely reacting chemicals. The RMP chemical involved is Isopropylamine (IPA).

One of the facilities associated with this process is a storage tank for Isopropylamine (IPA) CAS No.: 75-31-0. This tank has a total capacity of about 29,000 gallons however, the maximum to be stored is approximately 26,000 gallons. The other facility is a process area which includes reactors in which a chemical reaction (acid-base) actually occurs and a new product (salt) is
formed.

In the processing area, to process a batch, a measured amount of water is added to the reactor initially.  One half of the concentrated wetcake (acid) material needed for a batch is added into the reactor by mechanical augering.  After an amount of the concentrated wetcake is added to the reactor, isopropylamine (IPA) (base) is added at a fairly constant rate through a dip tube with an associated valve system beginning the reaction.  After the first reaction is com

pleted, the other half of the wetcake is added to the reactor and then the other half of the IPA is added and the second reaction takes place. After the second reaction has stabilized, a final amount of water is added to achieve the desired pH and assay.

The reaction is exothermic. Once the reaction begins, the temperatures in the reactor vessel will be higher than the boiling point of the IPA. The temperature of the reaction is primarily controlled by the feed rate of the IPA.  

The reactors are cooled by use of cooling water circulated through the coils on the reactors which will also help control the temperature of the reaction.  The heated cooling water is cooled by passing it through a 200 ton cooling tower. 

Gases released from the each reactor first pass through a water scrubber which has provisions to reinject the material vaporized back in to the reactor. Gases passing through the water scrubber pass through an acid scrubber. The two scubbers nearly eliminate all of the gaseous pollutants.

General Accidental Release Prevention and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps
These facilities are subject to the OSHA PSM standard therefore, enhanced chemical safety procedures are involved. The Schirm plant has been subject to the OSHA emergency response requirements for many years.

Based primarily upon volumes involved, the risk of an accident involving IPA is much greater at the storage tank. IPA is pumped to the processing facility in measured amounts and is reacted quickly as it is added to the reactor. After addition to reactors, hazard from IPA is nearly eliminated under normal operating conditions.
 
At the storage tank, hazards are to be minimized by use of several procedural and equipment safeguards: 
¿	Additional IPA is not supposed to be ordered unless the tank level is below the level that would accommodate a truckload of IPA thus helping to prevent over-filling. 
¿	There are high level alarms attached to liquid level sensors that are mou

nted in the tank. 
¿	Weight alarms are also included which are associated with load cells.
¿	The tank has a nitrogen blanket and a positive pressure of about 5 psi is maintained
¿	Personnel are to be present during filling and they would be aware of the situation and could use the emergency cutoff located at the tank area.  
¿	Fire Extinguishers are available in the area
¿	The tank is located in an area of the plant site that is farthest away from residences
¿	The tank is located with a diked area which includes a chemical resistant membrane
¿	A water deluge system is located around the tank
¿	Grounding equipment is available
¿	Only Personnel trained in the procedures for filling this tank and the emergency procedures are allowed to perform tank operations.
¿	Flame detectors which directly notify emergency responders are located at the tank site 


Numerous safeguards have been designed into the processing facility including procedural as well as equipment. 
¿	A primary safeguard is that the process is computer controlled which has numerous interlocks built in to prevent accidental incompatible actions 
¿	There is an extensive system of sensors and valve control devices that are routed to the process control computers located in the Control Room.  This allows accurate measurement of the amounts of materials that are being added, the temperatures, and the pH of various liquids involved and will allow control of the temperatures, pH, and amounts through use of electronically controlled valves. Various interlocks are included to assure valves and other devices are operated at the proper time and in the proper sequence. 
¿	Although the processes are computer controlled, they are not fully automated. The operators must tell the computer what activity to perform. This is a safeguard in that it requires constant monitoring by an operator. 
¿	Reactors are mounted on load cells thus providing a redundancy in determining the quantities of materials added to t

team as well as local responders.

Planned Changes to improve Safety
Identification of possible Safety improvements is a continual process. Minor changes or clarifications to safety procedures may be handled fairly directly. Major changes to procedures and/or when equipment is needed would require more formal training and documentation in accordance with management of change requirements. Operator's performances are monitored by their supervisor and randomly checked by management personnel. 

These are relatively new facilities and no major changes to the initial procedures and/or equipment have been identified. A review of operating & safety procedures has been completed recently and some editorial revisions are being included in the documents. General emergency response training has recently been completed and refresher training for the subject facilities is planned in the near future.
